titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: Women be no meet vessels to rule or to preach, for both are forbidden them: yet hath God endowed them with his Sprit at sundry times, & showed his power & goodness upon them, & wrought wonderful things by them, because he would not have them despised. We read that women have judged all Israel, & have been great prophetesses, & have done mighty deeds. Yea, & if stories be true, women have preached since the opening of the new testament. Do not our women now christen & minister the sacrament of baptism in time of need?
Might they not, by as good reason, preach also, if necessity required
? If a woman were driven into some island, where Christ was never preached, might she there not preach him, if she had the gift thereto? Might she not also baptize?
And why might she not, by the same reason, minister the sacrament of the body & blood of Christ, and teach them how to choose officers & ministers?
v. Tyndale. "Answer unto Sir Thomas More's Dialogue" p.18 (Parker Society).
A beautiful day, sunny and calm yet fresh. I worked all the morning at the lecture. There came to lunch a young man, named
Luke's, Darlington, who desires to add a chancel to his church: and
, who came for a walk in the Park. After lunch,
& I walked in the Park for an hour and a half. I was much pleased with his conversation. After tea I resumed work on the lecture, of which I have now written rather less than half.
